description.text: Vertical is a clip in, the horizontal is a bolt down

This thing is meant to sit in a standard Solo plastic cup. It allows you to place an avocado pit in it and it will hold it in place better than the normal toothpicks that are used. Plus it is 3D printed and looks kind of neat.
Updated 6/13/2012: New Top Connector that snaps onto the cup; no glue necessary. Also added a fully assembled SKP.

1) Print the Full Plate or 3x Legs, 1x Top Connector and 1x Bottom Connector. I suggest printing with 2 perimeters, 0 solid layers, .125 fill density, honeycomb fill pattern, infill every 1 layers.
2) (Optional) Super-glue the parts together - be sure to keep the top and bottom connectors in the proper orientation since the slots are angled.
3) Place (optionally super-glue) the assembled thing into a Solo cup. I chose to glue it because it makes it completely sturdy.
4) Place the avocado pit in the thing pointy-side-up.
5) Fill with water to about half-way up the pit.
6) Place on a sunny windowsill and wait a few weeks. The pit should split at the top.
7) See here for more information: http://www.thehungrymouse.com/2009/09/09/how-to-grow-an-avocado-tree-from-an-avocado-pit/
8) Keep the cup so you can reuse it next time you crack open an avocado!

author: Greg76

description.text:
The latch on our hopper window broke, so I decided to print a new one!

The original piece used rivets for the hinge. I did not have any laying around, so I used a M4 sized nut and flat-head bolt. I know these are best used as fasteners, but due to the small rotation or the latch, it does not feel much resistance when rotating.

The bolt was cut into the correct length while the nut was threaded onto it. This allows the thread to keep functioning after the cut.

print_settings.Notes:: The support requirements are for the baffles only. The suppressor doesn't need any support if you make a big enough brim and print it vertically, thread end towards the build plate.

title: Mk23 Stubby suppressor and two different baffles kits

description.text:
This is originally made for Mk23 NBB airsoft pistol, but you can use it with any other 16mm threaded barrel.

There is no barrel threads on the model, so you can use force and screw the piece to your gun and let the metal threads do a proper threading to it. This technique worked just fine for me.

If you cut and fit proper sized foam pads inside the baffles, it will muffle the sound quite nicely.
First baffle kit is plain and dull, another one is with a stupid looking skull grinning. Pick one you like. :)

Please remember to mention my name if you distribute these files or post it on somewhere else.

If you like what I do, you can leave a tip! It would be highly appreciated!

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 3 Extended

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

30-100

Notes:

Best result will come with PLA, but I have done few with ABS and Nylon and they work just nice and dandy.

If the baffles feel too tight for the suppressor, print a 0.5% smaller new one or just use sand paper to take out the excess material. This can happen especially with ABS printing.

The support requirements are for the baffles only. The suppressor doesn't need any support if you make a big enough brim and print it vertically, thread end towards the build plate.

comments.text: the hole is too wide for the barrel, with the skull-less insert it attenuates little the noise; perfect aesthetics, if it worked, would be great
comments.author: aziodale

comments.text: You noticed, this is made for Mk23 pistol that has 16mm threads?
comments.author: aziodale

comments.text: I used it in a STTI MK23
comments.author: PH4SIK

comments.text:
The .stl is easy enough to import into any 3D modeling software and resize the hole if needed. Especially when that model is so simple in design.
The thread hole is exactly 16mm wide and if you consider the printable material shrinking into a certain degree (depending on material, .2-.6%), so when you have printed it, the hole has shrinked enough to take a firm grip when screwing the suppressor into place, thus eliminating the need for 16mm thread tap.
I have printed four of these with PLA, ABS and Nylon for my TM and ASG (STTI) Mk23's and they all work fine.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed the rack with the from (the side closer to the mounting holes) touching the build plate so that the support wouldn't be too cumbersome to remove.

description.text: This is a rack that I designed because I wanted a large external storage and had a few 2.5 inch hdd's laying around. I did a little amazon shopping and bought a couple SATA to USB cables so I can connect them to the computer. Hope this model is of use to you and if so upload your make of it, I'd love to see if you customized it or not and how you use it!

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk1

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

I printed the rack with the from (the side closer to the mounting holes) touching the build plate so that the support wouldn't be too cumbersome to remove.

Removing support material

Every support easily popped out, except for the little triangular corners. this could be avoided by only using support on angles > 60. Thats only if you have a little confidence in your printer, I just didn't want the print to get messed up on the last stretch of the 7 hour print. In the end these little notches were not that hard to remove.

What was this designed for?

I wanted a modular rack to store my hard drives, when I need more storage I could print a larger rack with ease. Along with a few SATA to USB 3.0 cables and a USB 3.0 hub this rack would clean my desk up tenfold

Modular

Again this model is a modular design, Ive left a Fusion360 file containing all of my work and a Step file. To be honest I've never needed to use step files but if you don't have Fusion360 the Step file might come in handy.

Customizing - There is a body called "bay" and another called "top" along with a completed object that I used to print. Each bay holds 2 SSD/HDD's just copy paste however many bays you want and use point to point object movement to position each bay directly on top of one another. After getting a suitable amount of storage you can use the same point to point object movement to position the "top" object.. well.. on the top. Now under the modify section you can combine all of the objects you created into a single body that you can now print.

I was building my first high powered rocket - a LOC Precision Aura - and I wanted a jig to epoxy the fins and launch lug on straight. I designed this thing to print a pair of jigs to stick in either end of the body tube - one end with engine mount. The fins are held with strips of thin plywood held with spring clamps & wedges. A piece of threaded rod with nuts on either end holds the launch lug in place, while putting the jigs in tension. This setup allowed me to epoxy all the fins and the launch lug at once.

Materials required
  • 2 plates
  • 2 adapters (body tube and/or engine mount)
  • Threaded rod or other long, thin rod or stick to hold launch lug. Longer than body tube.
  • 6 thin plywood strips to clamp fins (longer than body tube, ~1" or 3/4" wide, ~1/8" thick)
  • 3 (or 6) small plywood strips (~1/2" x 2") thicker than fin material for use as wedges.
  • 3 spring clamps
  • Epoxy (or glue for lower power rockets)
  • Paper towel to catch dripping epoxy
  • Take measurements and modify parameters in .SCAD file.
    • Inner diameter of body tube, and engine mount if applicable
    • Thickness of fin material
    • Thickness of plywood strips to clamp fins
    • Rod diameter - leave some clearance
    • Inner body tube diameter - leave ~0.5mm clearance
    • Engine mount inner diameter - leave ~0.5mm clearance
    • For very large body tubes, check to see if your printer is big enough - my Mosaic was big enough to do a 100mm diameter plate - plenty big for my 38mm diameter rocket.
    • Check other parameters to make sure they work for your situation.
  • Print 2 plates. I provided an STL for my situation.
  • Print 2 adapters - one to fit each end of the body tube, which may have an engine mount in one end. I provided adapter STL files for a 38mm body tube and 29mm motor mount.
  • Check fit of adapters into body tube and engine mount - I had to reprint one, and reduce the others with a file.
  • Attach the adapters to the plates with an M3 cap screw and nut. I put the paper towel in between the adapter and bottom plate to catch epoxy, cutting slots for the fins and rod to hold the launch lug.
  • My body tube was pre-marked with lines for the lug and fins. You can mark a straight line by laying the body tube next to a straight piece of wood on a flat surface and using it as a ruler.
  • Put threaded rod through the enclosed slot on one jig. Slip launch lug over it. Put rod through other slot. Put nuts on either end. Make sure one end is inside the fin slot blisters so it can stand on that end. Align with line marked on tube. Tighten nuts.
  • Put a pair of plywood strips in each set of slots. Put fin between the strips up on body tube where there is room. Slide fins down until they reach the location along the body tube desired. In my case, the fins stuck into the bottom jig slots. If you want the fins up higher, you may need a 2nd set of plywood wedges.
  • Attach spring clamps to the plywood strips just above the fins to hold them.
  • You may notice a slight gap between the fins and body tube. I fixed this by pulling the upper end of the plywood strips away from the body tube until they are part of the way out from the body tube. Then, stuff the plywood wedges in between the strips above the jig until the strips are firmly held in the upper slots. Now, push the top of the strips into the slots. This will push the fins firmly against the body tube.
  • Now that you know where everything goes, pull the strips a little ways out from the top of the body tube, apply epoxy between the base of the fins and body tube, and push them back against the body tube. Loosen one nut on the rod holding the launch lug and apply epoxy at the correct position. Mine was ~half way up the tube. Press rod against the body tube at top and bottom and tighten nuts.
  • Now that the fins and launch lug are firmly secured, you may be able to stand the whole assembly upright. If not, find a way to support it vertically so that if the epoxy runs, it runs down symmetrically.
  • Once the epoxy is dry, apply thickened epoxy fillets to the base of the fins and launch lug. Allow to dry.

This is made for an FT-5 but could be used for any printer. I left out the support braces between the front and back plate as I just used the old ones that came with my printer. It fits 2 E3D V6 heads and a z height sensor as close together as I could put them. The extruder portion is in separate pieces as to be easily replaceable instead of having to reprint the whole front and replace it. Included is also the fan duct that I made to fit both extruders which can also be found here. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2476944

Extruders are 25.5mm apart. (x axis)

*Everything was tested with ABS so might be loose with other materials.

This tile set has been superseded by the much improved OpenForge 2.0 Tudor set. That set is both more complete, and vastly better designed, please, check it out. OpenForge
=========
Wood tiles designed to be compatible with Dwarven Forge dungeon tiles.
Compatible tiles/walls in this series are tagged with OpenForge
You can find this set on github
OpenForge Sets
=============
  • Smooth Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc.
  • Smooth Edge Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc. Edge tiles.
  • Stone Tile Series - Stone tiles.
  • Stone Edge Tile Series - Stone edge tiles.
  • Crenelated Tile Series - Crenelated Tiles
  • Crenelated Edge Tile Series - Crenelated edge tiles
  • Tudor Tile Series - Tudor tiles.
  • Tudor Edge Tile Series - Tudor edge tiles.
  • Ruined Series - Ruined stone walls
  • Accessories - Pillars, etc.
  • Non-Series Tiles - Misc tiles, such as the pool
  • Module Specific Tiles - Tiles designed for specific modules.
    • OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our website, at our forums, or on twitter and facebook.

Printed in black. Dry brushed with dark brown and then used ever lighter shades in the dry brush. To lighten, used a light leather, not a white in order to get more yellow in the highlights.
Due to the surface texture, the wood tiles seem to take a long time to slice. I'm working on figuring out how to keep a good texture while simplifying that.

comments.text: Why dont use the ejector while resizing? I dont use the priming feature of the press, so resizing and depriming  would be faster with the ejector installed.
comments.author: jpmaverick

comments.text:

description.text:
Anyone who has bought the FLSUN kossel mini kit knows the 40mm radial fan that is included with the kit is basically useless. I have tried other fan shrouds that have been posted to thingiverse, but haven't seen much of an improvement. So I designed my own, and here it is.

It uses a conventional 40mm fan, as opposed to the radial fan included with the printer kit.

title: Magic Nut Thing!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
We will be taking a look at the "Magic Nut Thing" as a vision that came to me in a waking dream, well in reality I was driving or something but the "waking dream" I figured would get more views. However as they say necessity is the mother of invention and success has many fathers until they all go to the Maury Povich Show with DNA in hand. Yet this is one of those things that I did a "self" why didn't we think of this before! As the neat thing is, it is ambidextrous so nut or bolt doesn't matter as one model fits all. On top of the fact if you want to glue them in you can but don't have to and the second (containing the nut) hides the bolt from the first adding not only a nice cosmetic feature but all a safety one too!

I have started my uploading what I feel the most common size used will be and that is a 1/4 Inch nut/bolt version for cinching or attaching various things. If you need a custom size we have the code published on our Open-SCAD site ( http://openscad.diy3dtech.com/magic-nut-thing/) however it does require the devloper version (2017.01.20) to run which can be found here ( http://www.openscad.org/downloads.html ) for download. Also if you run this it takes a lot CPU horse power as the knurling library (which this was designed upon) creates a huge surface area and cause some systems to lockup.

Build Note: Suggest printing one out and matching it to your nut/bolt combo and if the size is too far (different plastics will yield different results) than simply use the scale function in your slicer to adjust the size.

Open-SCAD Fans: we also have a video out on the Open-SCAD Channel at https://youtu.be/qRvlzpm-In0 if you want to check this out, as well as we have made the code available here: http://openscad.diy3dtech.com/magic-nut-thing/ if want to mess around with it yourself!

Also, please follow us on Thingiverse and give this a like if this came in handy and for more information on this project, please visit us at http://www.DIY3DTech.com as well as subscribe to our YouTube Channel at http://YouTube.DIY3DTech.com along with a visit to our drone site and YouTube channel at http://video-drone.DIY3DTech.com

If you are looking for one of a kind swag shop for yourself or a Maker Geek friend, visit our swag shop at http://Swag.DIY3DTech.com for unique 3D Printing, Laser Cutting and CNC swag! Too, if you want a behind the scene look at what we are working on be sure to follow us on Instagram (https://www.instagram.com/diy3dtech/)!

Any basically...

title: 101 Super Hero Upgrades (Power supply, Base and LCD Mount)

description.text:
These are parts I designed to make the 101 hero more kid friendly by hiding some of the exposed power supply wiring and circuitry of the full graphic controller when using the ramps 1.4 setup. They are designed to use minimal support and they slide over the pylons to not only protect your electronics, but add to the printer stability.

The base pieces were designed to be used with a setup including NEMA 17 motors

When Assembling the base, it is easiest to disconnect the belt from the pylons to allow for enough slack to position the motors.

Base pieces use the existing black screw from the original 101 Hero Stepper Motors to attach the base to the pylon. They also use 2x 12mm m3 screws to connect the nema 17 stepper motors to the base piece.

Pro Tip for attaching pylon base pieces: Insert the M3 screws for the motor mount before attaching the base to the pylon. This will make it easier to line up your screw-driver through the holes in the front with the screw inside.

**I have not tried the vented pieces yet, but the non switch versions support a 40mm fan and the switch version (vented and non-vented) will support the following switch assembly:
https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00511QVVK?psc=1

If you have any questions, feel free to post a comment. Time to take a nap!

title: Mk2B Bed Modification for Anet A8

description.text:
I upgraded my heated bed to a Mk2B heater pcb and borosilicate glass plate recently, thought I'd share the construction information and the printable parts.

Why upgrade? The aluminium plate is heavy, and because it heats up unevenly (hotter in the middle and cooler at the edges) it warps, making printing difficult, especially when you want a 0.1mm first layer.

The borosilicate glass makes an excellent build surface, and because it has a very low coefficient of thermal expansion it stays very flat.

Using larger, M4 screws to support the bed makes it more stable, and more durable.

So, by replacing the stock bed I've saved approximately 300 grams mass in the y axis, and have a very flat build surface. My print quality is excellent and I have no regrets.

You will need:
1x Mk2B heater pcb
1x 213mm x 200mm borosilicate glass plate
1x 100K NTC glass body thermistor
4x M4 x 35mm hex head bolts (or #8-32 x 1.5")
4x M4 (or #8-32) half nuts
4x binder clips
Kapton tape, and some strands of copper wire (I used strands from some 7/0.2mm equipment wire I had lying around, but almost any wire will do if you can solder it).

Tools:
An M4 or #8-32 tap to re-thread the holes in the H frame
A soldering iron and solder
A digital multimeter

Method:
Choose the adjuster/locknut file, M4 or #8-32) for the hardware you have.
Start by printing the adjusters, lock wheels and caps - you need 8 wheels and 4 caps. Press the half nuts and bolt heads into the wheels.

Next, remove the old bed and de-solder or cut the wires. Also remove the screws and springs, you won't need them.

Take the thermistor and solder a strand of copper wire to each leg, long enough to reach the edge of the bed. Next, tape the thermistor to the underside of the pcb, there's a hole in the centre which is the perfect location. Tape the wires in place so they aren't touching and solder to the original thermistor cable (the two thin white wires).

Test the thermistor with a multimeter, it should read about 100K Ohms at room temperature, and fall slowly when you touch it.

Solder the heater wires to the pads provided. The Mk2B heater pcb is designed for either 12V or 24V supplies, so make sure you use the 12V option. Ignore the pads for the resistor and LEDs, they are not needed.

Secure the cables - I used two zip ties, one around the cables, the second looped through the hole in the PCB and through the first tie. This should provide adequate strain relief.

Next, use the M4 (or #8-32) tap to re-thread the holes at each corner of the H frame, no need to drill out the M3 holes first.

Screw the bolts with the adjuster and lock wheels in place through the H frame as per the diagram, and position the caps on top.

Rest the PCB on the caps, they should locate in the holes at each corner.

Position the glass on top of the PCB so the screw caps aren't obstructed and secure with the binder clips. I find that placing the clips at the sides rather than the front and back edges works best.

Connect your bed and thermistor to the main board, level your bed and you're good to go!

I've been using this setup since June 2017 without problems. The bed heats up really quickly and the glass is the best build surface I've tried. A smear of ABS Juice on the glass is all you need for good adhesion, and the print will come loose when the bed temperature drops below about 40C.

PS, be careful - if you run the nozzle into the bed you'll most likely break the glass.

Update! I've re-designed the caps, they are longer now, and have an M4 thread internally, making them a bit more stable. See below for print settings.

Update! I've added the adjuster-locknut and cap mesh for #8-32 bolts. :)

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm for the wheels, 0.1mm for the caps (thanks MVH)

Infill:

20% for the wheels, 100% for the caps.

Notes:

Turn the wheels so the hexagonal pocket is uppermost. You can print all 8 in one go or one at a time, it's up to you.

You might want to experiment with Cura's Horizontal Expansion feature for the caps, I found the threads were a bit tight but with Horizontal Expansion set to -0.075 they fitted perfectly.

I printed mine with PLA at 190C.

Search eBay for '3D Printer PCB Heatbed', and 'borosilicate glass 200 213'.

I paid around £6GBP for my heater pcb, and around £11GBP for the borosilicate glass.

The thermistor can be found by searching for '100k ntc glass', they are very cheap.

100K NTC glass body thermistor

The nuts and bolts should be easy to find, I prefer A2 stainless.

The M4 tap - you only need the taper tap, not the whole set. This is a very useful addition to your 3d printer tool kit (if you don't already have one)!

M4 HSS three flute taper tap

You can find all my Anet A8 upgrades here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/FredGenius/collections/anet-a8-upgrades

I also highly recommend this Front Frame Brace by Leo Nutz:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1857991

print_settings.Notes:: Printed in durable resin. I let software decide the orientation. For other technologies, no idea which might be the optimal orientation. Probably you need some supports.

title: Replacement Konix Speed King joystick handle

description.text:
Replacement handle for Konix Speed King.

The inner hole in the first print was probably a bit too deep (doesn't matter that much with flexible enough material). I added M2 nut to keep it slightly higher.

Since Form 2 has rather nice resolution, I made the polycount rather high, as I wanted the handle as round as possible.

The uploaded model has slightly less deep hole, but haven't tried 3D printing that yet. (And current version is good enough anyway...). If you need, you can adjust it further in the included OpenSCAD source.

With durable resin, the stick seems to fit tight enough.

Can't say much about durability yet (haven't tried Decathlon yet), but it feels that the material will likely bend, rather than snap.

author: wincheat02

title: Setup for 4mm ID/6mm OD Bowden Tube (Ultimaker)

description.text:
I had a problem with my original tube, it was a slightly small diameter and even the stock Ultimaker PLA wouldn't pass
through it. I obtained a new PFA tube and ran into issues getting it to hold it in both ends tight enough (the original bowden tube is slightly larger on the outside). Hoping these instructions save you that grief! :D As an added bonus the new tube is way less finicky about filament thickness.

• Obtain a PFA tube 67cm long, with a 4mm inner diameter and a 6mm outer diameter.
  • Print out all the items for Owen's Bowden Clamp. Use V2. Skip the tightening cone. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11864
  • Print out all the items for pit3k's Bowden Clamp (Feeder End). Skip the tightening cone. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17027
  • Print out two copies of this tightening cone. This is what you will use whenever the above mention a tightening cone.
  • Install both bowden clamps, using your new PFA tube instead of your old bowden tube.
    • -=-=-=- Since Makerbot's latest changes I've felt uncomfortable with Thingiverse. I have switched most of my licenses to NC no derivatives. As this is a derivative of two open models I cannot change the license on this, so instead I've decided to remove it from Thingiverse. Send me a message if you are interested in obtaining this STL and I will be happy to send a copy.

remixed_from.title: Blank Universal tool mount for MPCNC 525

title: Blank Universal tool mount for MPCNC 525 remix by Brink

description.text:
I mixed in and printed wbarber69's in a tool mount I was working on before I realized that the shoulder on the insides of the holes were very thin. My tool was substantial and I feared that it would rip those thin shoulders right out of the back of the mount plate. I ended up using washers on mine that made the screws grab the front of the hole. I thought though that I would beef up the thickness of the shoulders since it was easy for me to do so and my help someone else who wished to use wbarber69's design in their project.

This is the same as wbarber69's mount except for thicker shoulders inside the mount holes. The screw heads wont go as deep and there is more "meat" for the screw to grab hold of.
Includes only stl file.

A filament guide for the Geeetech I3 Pro B. I use a rear-mounted spool holder and this guide allows me to use the full Z height of the printer. The guide attaches to the mounting holes in the LCD cover plate. It is a press-fit, so no screws are needed.

This is a remix of my original Sci Fi walls.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2472303
I wanted to give more room for expansion so I modified them. Check back, I'll be adding more styles as I think of them.

I added a cap and separate door and window inserts for a more detailed look. This allows the external face of the wall to have some texture as well. This also allows me to make these walls stackable and to add clip on flooring, even on multiple levels.

The walls with the cap and stands are 35mm tall, matching the height of dutchmogul's models. They're 1, 2 and 3 segments long, with each segment being 20mm long. This makes the wall segments 20x35, 40x35 and 60x45. The walls are actually 33mm tall and the cap and stand adds 1mm height each. The stands should clip on and hold just fine or you can glue them.

Because everyone's printer is different, you may have to adjust print settings to get it just right. If you're over extruding or printing too hot, things might be pretty tight.

title: Split Loom Clips for OpenBuilds V-slot Extrusions
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This/These are wire-loom clips that fit into OpenBuilds V-slot extrusions, used in quite a few 3D printers. They allow you to clip the wire bundles to the printer frame.

There's a few on here, but the ones I'd found for 1/2" split-loom were too small, seeming to target 1/2" outer diameter, rather than 1/2" inner diameter.

The initial one uploaded is 17mm inner diameter, which fits the common half-inch plastic split-loom wire wrap. Its 1.5mm thick, sized specifically to print tightly with two shells with a .4mm nozzle, and thin enough to still be flexible even in PLA to fit around the wire bundle.

The model is parametric, so I'm happy to upload other sizes if needed. Just post a request in the comments. I need to take some measurements, but I'll also be uploading one for 1/4 split loom, asap.

Edit: Added a 10mm inner-diameter one, which fits 1/4" split loom.
Edit 2: Also added a 13mm one, which fits 3/8" split loom.

title: Oculus touch - Gun Stock streamlined
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a streamlined remix of the Oculus gun stock by Gurgelx. It has been adjusted to be Easier to handle, use less filament and be put together entirely without extra hardware or glue. All parts ave been friction welded together and cleaned up in post processing. I have even made pins which can be printed to allow the rail mounts to be adjusted. i have also included an optional, shorter stock.

The reinforcement brackets are designed to slide onto the bottom rail and, well, reinforce the joints. These are however optional.

You need to print
2 x Rail Body.stl (rails)
1 x Rail End.stl (end of rail)
2 x touch rail adapter (rail mounts)
1 x Stock clip (stock mount)
1 x touch-stock-mk2.stl or MK2
1 x touch-mount-left-mk3.stl
1 x touch-mount-right-mk3.stl
2 x pin.stl

construction is self explanatory., But message or comment for help.

FlashForge

Printer:

Finder

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.18

Infill:

10%

Notes:

4x perimeter with 0.4mm extruder

All parts friction welded together

No glue needed. Dremel used to friction weld parts together where needed

Sanding

Mainly sanding down welding so leave a smoother finish

Painting

I ran out of grey filament and had to switch to blue. Black looks better.

comments.text: The taper that everyone is commenting about was an easy fix in Fusion 360, just required a single extrude along the length of the body of one side to the other. I attached the two body parts in a .7z compression file.

comments.text: I read the comments before printing and spotted the "tapering" issue that's been mentioned. I loaded the Rail_body.stl and Rail_end.stl files into Cura 3.2.1 and found that I had the same issue. I took it one step further and loaded the files into Blender and found that the 3D model is, in fact, tapered on one side. I've attached a screenshot where I duplicated the rail body within Cura and flipped it round so you can compare the "male" end to the "female" end. On the "male" end you can see it's a few layers shorter on one side than on the "female" end. This problem also exists in the Rail_end.stl file.

title: 3 dimensional math exercise
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
What does a 3-dimensial object such that the top view is a circle, the front view is a isosceles triangle and the side view is a square look like?

Answer
The result is some kind of cylinder which has been tied together at the top.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

It is best to print the base with the square on the bottom, then no supports are needed.

Print the cone-like object on a slightly smaller scale, like 98%. This ensures a better fit. No infill is needed for the cone-like object
NGSS

When learning about projections, pupils can be asked to think of a 3-dimensial object such that the top view is a circle, the front view is a isosceles triangle and the side view is a square.
Not exactly trivial for students to find the object (and draw a sketch of it). The base can be given to the students to help them visualize the top, front and side view. When some students have found the solution, they can be given the cone-like object to verify the problem.

Problem What does a 3-dimensial object such that the top view is a circle, the front view is a isosceles triangle and the side view is a square look like? The base can be given to help the students visualize the problem
• spatial skills
5 to 10 minutes

title: Tool Mount for MPCNC 525 fits Porter Cable 890

description.text: This is a tool mount that fits a Porter Cable 890. You will want to print 2 of these even though only one is shown in the picture. It's 90mm diameter and may be usable for other similarly sized tools. This particular router may be a bit heavy for the MPCNC but it's one I already had. There is another 90mm mount on here but the PC890 had the height rack on the side as well as the keyway pegs that made using that one difficult. I did not want to remove the rack or modify my router in any way so I made this to be able to mount it as is.

description.text:
This is a leg to fit most common clothes drying racks.

Clothes drying rack tends to scratch the floor, when its legs go missing. On carpet I wouldn't even care, but on natural parquette you have to have them.

It is my first parametric fusion 360 model after I learned Fusion 360 thanks to the https://www.youtube.com/TheMakersMuse channel. So I am sure that it can be done even more beautifully.

Printed in Prusa PETg on Prusa Original MK2 (sliced .gcode provided).

No supports needed.

description.text: Test

I saw the original video by FLOWALISTIK, and loved his idea. I ended up recreating it in Tinkercad to make it narrower so it would fit my tripod's release plate. I made it shorter as well, because I use a smartphone as my camera so I don't have the lenses and need the length, and I wanted it to print faster since I was using the lab at the local library and had time constraints.

For the projector platform I rebuilt the remix from MarcoMota01 because I tried to print it on a Robo and it didn't slice properly, so I just rebuilt it from scratch. I printed everything out, and found that it was too wide to fit in the hole and had to modify it with a rotary tool, so I have modified the platform pattern and hopefully it will be narrow enough now.

The dimensions of quick release plate this fits are about 43mm on the bottom, 35mm on the top, and 8mm tall (actual height, not distance along the edge). The glass I used was 2.5mm thick and it fit well.

title: Yi 4K Case for Walkera G-2D Gimbal (or standalone)

description.text:
Originally designed by tohendo and remixed by Krynin, I further modified this Yi 4K case for use with the Walkera G-2D gimbal.

My additions include holes for the microphones and the speaker, a hole to access the USB port on the side, and pre-punched holes for the Walkera G-2D gimbal arm screws. I have also added a hole on the bottom to access the 1/4" socket mount if you just want to use this case by itself on a tripod to protect the camera.

Where Krynin's design had the cover on the back, I have moved it to the front and have added an extensive integrated lens protector and a hole for the indicator light to shine through. The cover can be held on with a cable tie or a standard velcro strap. There is also a hole on the back of the case to make it easier to eject the camera when it comes time to access the data card.

To use this case with the Walkera G-2D gimbal, you will have to remove the stock GoPro holder by removing the two hex screws on the arm of the tilt motor. You will also have to remove the gyro board on the back of the stock holder by removing the four screws and snipping the plastic around the cable where it goes through the GoPro holder frame. I have included an STL file for a replacement gyro board holder that can be simply hot-glued to the back of the printed case, then you can use the stock cover and screws to secure the board. Then the whole assembly can be attached to the tilt motor arm using the stock screws with the pre-punched holes.

Keep in mind that this new case and camera will have a different balance from the standard GoPro holder, and you may have to balance the case with counterweight and/or adjust the power and gain for each motor according to the gimbal manual.

The bean tray of the DeLonghi Magnifica S is small. Using this Thing you will get a bean tray that is 36mm higher, creating enough room to load the contents of a 500 grams bag of beans. See the foto.

  • No need to store an opened bag in your cupboard anymore;
  • Less frequently need to do a bean-refill;
  • Original DeLonghi top fits on top of the extension;
  • Unexpected bonus feature: noise-reduction of the bean-grinding proces. It is now much more quiet!

Since it is small, thin and simple, it is very cheap to produce. Got this for under 10 euros.

I also created a higher one, 50mm, including a tunnel element giving access to the GrindedBeans area. A bit more expensive to get printed, but holds more beans!

description.text: I created this part so that I could replace 2 physical AA batteries with a part that allows me to provide power reliably from a bench power supply. This part allows me to attach the leads from the power supply to the screws (using the nut closest to the head of the screw), and also to be able to adjust the amount of engagement to the spring contacts in the battery compartment by turning the nuts further away from the head of the screw.

description.text: The beginning of a mounting system I designed for the DJI F330 quadcopter frame and clones. This landing gear incorporates a pair of holes meant for 8mm carbon fiber rods which pass underneath the frame from front to back, extending out each side. I have designed matching anti-vibration mounts for the Walkera G-2D gimbal for the front and a battery mounting plate for the back to balance out the weight. There is also a generic anti-vibration mounting plate. Check my other designs!

title: B-Wing x1 & x2 Holder (X-Wing Miniatures) for Stanley Organizer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Latest Update: August 10, 2017. See Below for more

I use the Stanley 25-Compartment Organizers for my X-Wing Miniatures collection, and have tried many solutions for maximizing space and keeping the models safe. I reviewed most of the similar designs on Thingiverse, but there were none that had everything I wanted. So I started to design my own series, and based on my collection (I own at least one of almost everything, including Epic).

My design goals:

  • Maximize Space
  • Attractive Presentation
  • Include the pilot cards
  • Include the movement dials whenever possible

So, here are my designs for the B-Wing. There are 2 different designs, one for 2x B-Wings with 4 pilot cards and one for 1x B-Wing with 2x pliot cards and 3x movement dials. Both designs also have a Flush and a Sunken version design (one flush top with sunken text, and one sunken top with raised text). The Sunken design allows the top of the Stanley Organizer to sit flush when closed, but personally I prefer the aesthetics of the Flush design. The pictures have one printed of each design.

This would be a great opportunity for dual-extrusion (but I don't have dual-extrusion yet. If there are requests, I can probably put up another version ready for dual-extrusion, instead of a cut-out design.

This will fit the Stanley 25 Compartment Organizer (https://amzn.com/B00005QWYF) or the Harbor Freight 20 Compartment version (https://www.harborfreight.com/tool-storage/part-storage/19-bin-portable-parts-storage-case-93928.html).

As I complete and post more of this collection, I will link them here as well.

  • A-Wing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397806
  • B-Wing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2477298
  • E-Wing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2404410
  • K-Wing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397829
  • Sabine's TIE Fighter: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397957
  • T-65 X-Wing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397667
  • T-70 X-Wing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397764
  • YT-1300: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397827
  • YT-2400: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397816
  • Movement Dial Holder (7x): https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2397958

Yes, I will be posting Empire and Scum as I get to them.

UPDATE: July 1, 2017: Most models now have a v3.1 design, with the top of the cup lowered by 3mm, which will allow the "nubs" on the top of the Stanley Organizer to close better. Also, to accomodate this, I changed the Text and Logos to Raised instead of Sunken.

UPDATE: August 10, 2017: B-Wing Added! I haven't had a lot of time recently, so new designs are slow to come, but I am working on them. I am re-doing the Y-Wing design (it was printed in a gold and in one of the pics). Also, for those looking for color differences in materials, the X-Wing, A-Wing, and double B-Wing cups were printed with SainSmart Red PLA. For the Single B-Wing, K-Wing, E-Wing, Attack Shuttle, YT-1300, YT-2400 and Sabine's TIE Fighter, I used the GP3D Red PLA. I must say that I MUCH prefer the color and finish of the GP3D Red over the SainSmart Red.

UPDATE: February 6, 2018: Life has kept me away from designing, so I haven't been able to work on any new designs in a while. I still intend to finish out the Rebel fleet, and then move on to the Imperials and Scum, but time will tell. In the interim, check out 3D_Pressure's Designs. While 3D_Pressure and I differ on a few design ideas, he has continued on in the spirit of my designs, and I really like some of his creative ideas.

Note #2: I know the YT-2400 and YT-1300 designs are a little tight sometimes. Next time I do a set of revisions, I will open up the hollow for both ships a little bit.

Printer:

Maker Select v2.1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 layers, 0.16 first layer

Infill:

20% (10% is fine too)

Notes:

Printed in PLA @ 200, Bed @ 65
40mm/sec, Retraction Enabled
GP3D RED PLA (http://amzn.to/2vn4mIC)

NOTE: The normal design includes "feet" on the cup, so supports are required. If you use the no-feet version, no supports are required. I have not tried printing upside down.
Paint or white crayon into the Rebel Logo & "T-65 X-Wing" text. Insert your pilot cards, movement dials and miniatures, then place inside your Stanley Organizer.

I printed this with the face down, and the printer had a hard time printing the edges of the wall plate. title: Modular boat propeller designed for 3D printing 80mm diameter

description.text:
This propeller is part of a bigger boat motor project that I'm working on, but I decided to publish this propeller in advance as it will take some time before the rest is finished, and maybe some one can find this useful.

Note! These blades are the first prototypes, I will make more blade designs to fit to this hub, so even if you only need the propeller and don't care about the rest of the project, check back here for more blades.

Specification

  • Outer diameter: roughly 80mm (a little bit more)
  • Blades: 3
  • Inclination: No idea. :)
  • Hub diameter: 32mm
  • Length: 27mm
  • Shaft bore: 6mm
  • Locking mechanism: 2mm hole for cotter pin
  • Screws: 3pcs M3x 8(min) - 16(max) (or skip screws and use glue).

What is special?
This prop is specially designed for 3D-printing. This means it's designed to be printed using minimum support (none), which makes the result much better and reduce processing time.
The prototype in the pictures has had no post-processing work.

In my experience, propeller blades are troublesome as they are so thin so when they are printed on support, they tend to bend, come loos, catch the print head causing layer shift and all sorts of problems. Not to mention the rough surface caused by the support... But you'll have none of those problems with this one! :)

It is also modular which means that you can replace one blade if it's damaged.
It's quite a big prop, and can it be down-scaled? yes, it all depends on your nozzle size and printer. Best way to find out is to try in the slicer and look at the layer previews, you'll see that when you downscale too much parts of the blades will get too thin to print, then you know the limit.

what is it designed for?
You'll see.... :)

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

The amount of infill you use depends on your material of choice and what you intend to use this for. If you're really going to push its limits, make sure you use a couple of perimeters and high infill. I used 6 perimeters and 40% infill on my prototype and it feels solid and very strong.
Designed using Fusion 360

comments.text: I made a modular 2 bladed prop designed to be powered by a 1hp weed wacker at 7000 rpm... I used ABS with 100% infill, but it would break if the weed wacker was above ~50% throttle when close to 0 mph. I ended up just gearing it down 3:1 and attaching a $10 trolling motor prop. from walmart... The larger diameter was more efficient for my explorer 200 than the 80mm diameter,  ~2.5" pitch prop designed for 7000 rpm :)
comments.author: Emancipator

comments.text: Yea, ~1000W is a lot. You also have to think about orientation for printing. The materal lines should go all the wy from the hub out to the blade tip undisturbed which means you have to print it basically with the axis of travel aligned with Z. I didn't care about that in this case, this propeller is strong enough for what I intended it for, however I ditched the original project (which was a quite big model outboard) It was too big, and I accidentally asked myself why I should put time into building something like that. :)  Now I work on a much smaller water jet instead.
comments.author: Emancipator

comments.text: Nice design but blade pitch must be steeper to the center of prop (twist)
comments.author: Ghiotto

comments.text: The blades have different pitch at the tip and the root, most clearly visible in the pic with the three blades on the build plate. Keep in mind that the root is already quite far out from the center of rotation also and the blades are short. But my intention with this modular design is to try different blade designs, this is just a first rough prototype, but runs smooth and creates lots of thrust in my first water tests here! :)
comments.author: Ghiotto

Holds plastic bags. 250mm tall, so you need a large format printer like a ROSTOCK MAX or ORION to print it.
I had an old IKEA bed frame for which the new slats did not fit. The new slats were narrower and more closely spaced.
The bullet bill from mario kart, with SWIVELLY ARMS :)

Print the stls (it should be obvious how many of each part). Lose a few pupils. Print replacements. Glue everything together, apart from the arms to the body. Once sanded down a little, the arms will click into the body, so they rotate but with enough friction to hold in place. Crash into people, and go POW! The body was made with an inkscape dxf, rotate extruded in openscad. The sleeves and eyes were openscad and hacky. The really hard bit were the arms, these were in blender, then openscadded to add pins and to cut them in half so they're printable. A fun project for today :) If anyone has improvements, I have a git repo here: https://github.com/JamesGlanville/bulletbill.git Submit pull requests with impunity :)

author: mandarim

title: geeetech i3 pro B X-axis rework

description.text:
Geeetech i3 pro B X axis rework based on Original Prusa MK2.
Original geeetech design have problem that tensioning of X axis belt deforming Z axis geometry.
This thing solve this problem. It is inspired by Original Prusa MK2 with this modifications:

  • Motor moved by 5mm left
  • distance between linear bearing rod and screw rod is 21mm
  • it is compatible with original geeetech M8 lead nut and T8trapezoid lead nut
  • better tensioning of belt
  • It is compatible with original passive idler pulley (M4 screw) or with smaller pulley (M3 screw)
  • holes for tensioner screw have thin 0.2mm wall to make it printable without support. Drill it before use or simply use force to screw M3 tensioner screws.
  • There is two versions of tensioner part. Both use M3 screw for tensioning. Difference is screw for pulley only. This can be M3 (pulley bore 3mm, pulley outer diameter 13mm, space for pulley 15.2mm) and M4 (pulley bore 4mm, pulley outer diameter 15mm, space for pulley 16mm)

OpenSCAD sources are available here https://github.com/dobryj/Original-Prusa-i3/tree/geeetech_i3_B

Made from PETG. Nozzle 0.3 or 0.4mm, Layer 0.2 mm. 30-40% infill. 4 perimeters. Without support. Use 8mm drill to calibrate holes for X axis rods.

It need 4 LM8UU or 2 LM8LUU bearings

I recomend use it together with https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:602481 and https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1721916

Edit 2016-08-11: Space between x-end-idler and x-tensioner is extended

comments.text: I actually have not printed this one yet, because the place where I print them does not have the exact colors I need. If I were to print this, I would print each piece in its own color and then assemble the pieces together. It is possible to just print pieces with arbitrary color and then paint over, but paint can be easily scraped off so it's not that good. I have printed other things (Spike:BANG, flower octet, etc.) and I found that they were extremely hard to assemble, because I had not accounted for tolerance. The pieces were always printed a little too big and they were nearly impossible to piece together unless the piece was really big. I had to use a vise clamp to push the pieces in. Thanks for looking at the design!

author: mandarim

title: Driven Element Box for VHF/UHF Antenna

description.text:
The idea behind this was to make and easy to build driven element for a 6m to 70cms Yagi (although it might be a bit big for a small 70cms beam) and incorporate a choke into the box. Now this might not be the best place for the choke but it is certainly neat

This project is primarily for a 7 element 6m portable contest antenna for the UKAC so I wanted to be able to put it all together as quickly as possible on site. The passive elements will clip into 10mm pipe clips on the supports. Very much like the 2m one that is on my blog. www.chopcat.co.uk if anyone is interested.

This is plan B of the prototype I have made and is shown in the photos. I made as separate elements and now have reduced the box to three bits. No longer needing the two brackets to clamp to the boom. After a short time trying to work out how to make my new R2 print now its touch screen has stopped working plan B is printed (in orange). This is the composite version of the box for a 30mm square boom.

Anyway I will update as I print more and fine tune with field tests.

Designed in sketchup and printed on an R2 in PLA so far.

author: mradamfletcher

description.text:
Clamp to strengthen 1515 verticals on Kossel XL

This double clamp is designed to slot into 1515 extrusion, allowing a second vertical 1515 extrusion to be tightly clamped to it. This effectively gives you 15x40 verticals, with very good radial stiffness. An essential point is that you can fix to a 1515 beam without having access to the end of the slot to put a nut in - so you can add the extra verticals without dismantling your printer. I have used 3 clamps per vertical on my Kossel XL. You need two 20mm M3 bolts per clamp.

Printer:

Kossel XL

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Print vertically to give strong prongs: the stl file is correctly orientated for printing.
Ensure extrusion is carefully calibrated as it is a tight fit
Carefully ease between prongs with a blade, then lever the two halves apart. Will need some cleanup to allow the prongs to mesh properly.
Used FreeCAD

This is a composition of hexagons made by 3D printing. Everyone is different.

Many of the pieces have been made by myself, but others have been adaptations of figures and textures that I found on the Internet. I'll try to find you and put my thanks here.
Thanks to all the people who inspired me!

This project remains open to the incorporation of more designs. If you want to contribute yours in this series you can do it. Click on "Remix it" and it will be part of the project. I am collecting contributions here https://www.thingiverse.com/tecnoloxia_org/collections/100hex-contributions/

Some of the stl files need to be scaled. Dimensions are
hexagon 60 mm side
X: 120 mm
Y: 103.923 - 104 mm
Z: 2 mm

Twitter: @100hex https://twitter.com/100hex

- - - - - -

This project participated in the OSHWDem 2017. We built a mural for this year's Clone Wars challenge. https://oshwdem.org/2017/11/reto-de-impresion-3d-clonewars-2017/
You can see the result in the maker room of the Domus Sciencie Museum (A Coruña)

- - - - - -

For the preparation of the pieces I have used

  • Direct programming for the generation of recurring figures, functions and fractals: Openscad, BlocksCAD, geogebra, processing
  • CAD Drawing with Onshape
  • Hand made drawing and photos treated with gimp and with inkscape, and then I have generated the stl file with openscad

author: HorizonLab

description.text:
This is a data connector for some of the Chinese calipers and tire depth gauges. If the button layout is the same as shown in the pictures, this connector will probably work.

Print both STLs at 0.1mm layer height, 20% infill, no support, with just a skirt, no brim (if you print with a brim it’s a pain to cleanup)

For wire I used 26AWG 1.27mm pitch flat cable. This is the ubiquitous “jumper cable” product you get with Dupont connectors already attached.

For this connector you need 4 conductors, any color. Strip 2cm of insulation off one end as shown in the pictures. Apply solder to the first 15mm of wire from the tip to stiffen the wire. After cleaning up the print of Connector.stl, use a 1.5mm drill bit to enlarge the exit holes and to remove any material in between. The goal is to be able to insert all 4 insulated conductors bonded together as shown in the picture. Using the ConnectorNoHandle print, place the 4 soldered conductors in the 1.5mm on center cuts and use this as a guide to insert the wires into the connector with a handle. After verifying that you’re able to insert the insulated cable into the exit holes approximately 5mm, withdraw the wire till the bare wires are exposed. Apply some plastic epoxy to the insulation and reinsert the wires. Put the assembly aside and wait for the epoxy to cure. Once cured fold the 4 wires around the end of the connector, cleaning up the soldered ends as needed.

The data and clock signals coming from the caliper are 1.5v. I’ve included a simple circuit to level shift to 5V (VCC in the circuit). The only reason I used a comparator to do the level shifting is that that’s what I had on hand. Use whatever you have available to do the unidirectional level shifting. Note that you DO NOT want a bidirectional circuit.

I’ve also included a simple Arduino sketch so you can see the raw data coming from the caliper.

The pin assignments, as shown in the pictures:
Green - GND
Blue - DATA
Purple - CLOCK
Gray - +1.5V

I chose a tire gauge because it’s cheap (~US$4), and it meets the future use as a height data probe for a project I’m starting. If you attach a low force spring to keep the caliper probe extended, then attach the tire gauge to a servo, Vwa-lah, you have a really inexpensive data probe.

https://www.aliexpress.com/item/WSFS-Hot-Digital-depth-gauge-caliper-tread-depth-gauge-LCD-Tyre-tread-gauge/32775295632.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.FIUyIk

Note that the price varies. When I bought mine it was offered for less than US$4. I bought a few more at another site for a little less. If the unit body looks like the gauge/caliper in the picture, it’s probably OK.

Update 11-AUG-2017: Modified ConnectorNoHandle.stl so that insulated wires can be epoxied the same as the connector with a handle.

Update 22-AUG-2017: I uploaded a picture of my test setup. The caliper is being powered by a DC-DC regulator (shown in the beige box) to supply 1.5V. The data is being monitored by an ATTiny85, turning the caliper into an I2C device. Whenever the value changes, the ATTiny85 sets a signal wire high. The Arduino Pro mini, acting as the I2C master, then requests 3 bytes from the ATTiny85 via I2C. The ATTiny85 then resets the signal wire. If change notification isn’t needed, the master can, at any time, request the latest value from the ATTiny85 via I2C. If anyone is interested in the Arduino projects for what’s described in this update, let me know and I’ll upload them

Update 28-OCT-2017: See https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2612218 for an implementation example that uses an I2C interface.

title: 28BYJ-48 supports and pulleys
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Here you have some thing that can help you to make projects with the popular 28BYJ-48 stepper motor. There are two supports, one to be used in a horizontal surface and other for a vertical surface.

To hold the other end of the belt I included two ball bearing supports, one with a long screw that can be used to adjust the belt tension. MT2 5 or 6 mm belts can be used. There are also 30 and 15 teeth pulleys that fit well to this motor. You will need some tiny washers, I usually use a piece of copper wire around the screw. The ball bearings are 5mm internal diameter and 10 mm external diameter.

The screws that hold the ball bearings are #10, 1” long, the screw used to adjust the belt is a #6. Motors are held in place using small 1/8” screws if you thread the holes or you can use self tapping screws.

description.text: I made this to add a cooling fan to my Printrbot simple for the extruder motor. The Extruder was getting very hot after printing for more than an hour so I made this to keep it cool. It works very well. The motor now runs cool, its not even warm to the touch anymore.  It connects to the screw holes on the top of the Y axis. You will need to wire up a power supply for this fan. I use a ATX power supply, with the fan wired to an old hard drive connector. I meant to clean this up alittle, but I deleted my save file. So for now this is the final version till I remake it.
customized with 3D Slash!

print_settings.Notes:: I only used supports for the arms since they are not flat.  You can probably just infill everything at 20%, but I decided to print my arms at 30% just in case.

description.text:
I decided to remix this so instead of creating a new part to mount on the existing cocking sleeve, I should just design two cocking arms that bolt directly to the front grip and breach sled.

You just need to get two screws for the front grip or redesign the arms holes and front grip holes for the screw of your type. The screw I used on hand was a M4-0.7x8 screws. You can use the existing sled screws for the inner part, just thread them in through your printed arms.

It took me three tries to get the arms at a correct length and it's almost perfect for me.

Have fun,happy modding.

BTW, the original Barrel file and front grip files are perfect. Kudos to the original designer.

Gaming grip for the New 2DS XL. Doesn't block any ports and has a slot for the speakers. The three parts just glue together, I used Loctite super glue. The indent from the holder can be used as a guide for gluing and the flat ends of the grips should be flush with the back of the holder. It stops my hands cramping on long gaming sessions so hope this helps some people. There is a small gap when the 2DS lid is closed with the grip on but it still turns off normally and shouldn't interfere with anything.

updated 6.23.2012
This is a small corn hole set that can be used with one to four players.
Use the flippers to flip small 'bean bags' into the hole or at least onto the board to score points.
WARNING: IT IS DIFFICULT TO GET THE BEAN BAG IN CORN HOLE. WE GAVE UP AND STARTED SHOOTING AT A SMALL BOWL.

Your will need:
  • print at least one corn_hole_120611a.stl
  • print one flipper_2_120616c_ctr.stl for each player
  • four "bean bags" for each player (a different color for each player)
  • "Bean bags" can be made from small pieces of duct tape 6 mm round or square stuck together
    --- small pieces of colored Play Doh or modeling clay may also work
    • The original flipper was difficult to control distance and direction so I recommend use of the updated flipper (flipper_2_120616c_ctr.stl) with the trigger. to launch your bean bag:
  • place the "bean bag" in the flipper
  • set the trigger in one of the notches for distance
  • carefully center the flipper in the notch for accurate direction control
  • carefully pull the trigger back for a consistent release
    • Rules and scoring for corn hole are available from the American Corn Association at http://www.playcornhole.org/rules.shtml

description.text:
I created these mounts to attach phone and networking equipment to walls and the bottoms of shelves in my equipment room and media center, but it should work for any relatively rectangular object.

Select 'Open in Customizer' on the right to tweak its dimensions to match the object you want to mount, set the size of the flat-headded screws you'd like to use, and adjust thicknesses and tooth sizes to to alter the strength of the grip on your object. You can create brackets that attach to the corners of your objects, or just the sides, so if you'd like you can create a variety of points of contact to suit your needs.

Theoretically these things could hold an arbitrary amount of weight depending on how thick you set the dimensions. Although, unless you're willing to alter the OpenSCAD source (which I've tried to make fairly easy) each bracket accommodates only one screw. So basically what I'm saying is try not to be stupid with these things, and if you disregard that advice don't blame me!

Github: https://github.com/dbenoy/3dprint-surface-mount

description.text:
A fully working loom, no need for any other materials ready to use from the printer, no need for metal screw( you can use them if you want)
You just need to print and assemble the parts, there a lots of tutorial videos of how to use it
I recommend 50% to 100% infill to support the thread tension, if your printer is too small you can rescale up to 75% and it will work with no problem, no supports needed.
after print is recommended to sand the parts so the thread will flow more easily.

you can make scarfs, tapestry, clothes, kumihimo, and anything you want there is no limit, you can use up to 44 threads in the loom wide, length haves no limit.

It needs some improvement inthe screws and the locking bars, please fell free to remix and improve the loom.

Update: I recommend to use metal screws, I uploaded a photo as an example, just find the correct size of screws cut the screw heads and use epoxy or superglue, they will work like magic

description.text:
TITO biped robot with EXTRAS
At last OTTO DIY has an updated older brother.

List of parts:
Arduino NANO with I/O shield
Small female to female jumper wires
Buzzer
Futaba servo S3003 x4 180 degree movement
HC-SR04 Ultrasound sensor
MAX 7219 LED matrix
Nuts M3 x20
Screws M3x12mm x20
Powerbank (optional 3.7 Volt LIPO and DC-DC boost converter to 5 Volt) or just use the usb for power the Arduino board.

Check the OTTO Plus for connections as this is based on this.
The HC-SR04 Ultrasound sensor is not shown connected in the schematic; (trigger to pin 8 and echo to pin 9)

For the programming:
Download & Install Arduino IDE:
https://www.arduino.cc/
Copy OTTO plus libraries to C:\Users\user\Documents\Arduino\libraries (or wherever your library folder is installed):
Finally open & upload OTTO_smooth_criminal.ino code to your Arduino Nano for dancing Otto.

Any problems printing or making or programming?
Join and create a topic in our group http://www.thingiverse.com/groups/ottodiy/

title: Lens Adapter Galaxy S7 Edge
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my binocular adapter for the galaxy s7 edge. You can see the difference the binoculars make with the photo I took of a tree in my front yard. To make the adapter (pictured in red), print out the cover and the female thread pieces separate. Print the threaded piece in high resolution to make sure it properly screws. Super-glue either side of the thread piece, carefully line up and stick it against the back of the cover.

The binocular with the light blue adapter is a small 6x16 binocular. The larger more common one is a 10x25 binocular. To make the adapter for the small binocular, print the small male base and screw pieces separately and stick together with super-glue. The large binocular adapter can be printed as one piece, which is why there's only one file.

Since the binoculars shake quite, I made a case for my phone to use on a tripod. There are three holes on the tripod case that are self threading. The holes should fit any regular tripod. Make sure to print the case upright.

When I started college last year, I decided to make a telescope adapter for astrophotography. Unfortunately, I forgot what size telescope I used and what diameter eyepiece the adapter fits on. The telescope adapter comes in two pieces, just like the small binocular adapter, and is put together the same way. I only show two moon photos above, but there are more on my website at (https://www.souzoumaker.com/blog-1/2017/8/8/lens-adapter).

author: dihydrogenmonoxide

print_settings.Notes:: Super easy print, you can use basically whatever settings you want

description.text:
The goal of this puzzle is to remove the large ring, printed in red in the images. Assemble the puzzle as shown in the first picture when you make it. The string is only required to be around 10cm long, but a length closer to 20cm makes solving the puzzle less finicky.

I first came across this puzzle on display with several others in a souvenir shop. After spending a fair amount of time messing with all the puzzles they had, this was the only one I couldn't solve, and so I decided I would buy it to be able to work on it on my own time. However, it wasn't on the shelf where all the other puzzles for sale were sitting, and when I asked the shop owner she said that the man who used to make them had passed away a few months ago. This meant that they couldn't get any more units in to sell, and the one on display was the last one they had.
So, having just assembled my first 3d printer a few weeks before, I decided to take some pictures and attempt to recreate it. After spending some quality time with the new plastic puzzle, I finally managed to figure it out for myself. Can you?

description.text:
This is a ultrasonic sensor mount. Intended use is to build a 3D model of the environment around it from polar coordinates.

I'm re-using models for the following sensor and motors, simplified and made slightly larger so they can fit in the printed frame.

  • 28BYJ-48 Stepper
  • TowerPro SG90 Servo
  • HC-SR04 Ultrasonic sensor

This is work in progress. There are 4 modules that should be printed separately, and screwed to the sensor or motor they hold.

  • base holds the stepper
  • tigeservo supports the servo holder
  • servoholder holds the servo
  • sensorholder holds the sensor

The arduino controller and esp-01 chatbot code is on GitHub.

description.text:
Last year I found this company's kickstarter (https://plasticbottlecutter.com/) and decided to make a 3d printed version of it. Please consider buying the original tool to support them.

I have a very detailed guide on my website (https://www.souzoumaker.com/blog-1/2017/8/7/bottle-cutter) for anyone who wants to make this tool. I've found the rope to be extremely useful, especially when towing FRC robots.

comments.text: This technique is quite old and many people in poorer countries (like Brazil) have been using it for a while to make a living out of up-cycling waste plastic bottles (into rope, brooms, fishing nets, etc.). Don't need to feel bad about using this design since the mentioned company didn't invent anything anyway! ;-)

print_settings.Notes:: Print with 4 perimeter lines (0.4mm wide) for greater strength and stiffness.  Print two of the pad parts and one each of the body, jaw, gear and pawl.

description.text:
This 110mm light-duty clamp uses a quick-adjusting rack & pinion to open and close the clamp, and a spring-release ratchet to hold the clamp shut. It prints with minimal supports and requires no additional fasteners.

https://youtu.be/42zKMKU1Nug

Printer:

UDIO

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30% (triangular)

Notes:

Print with 4 perimeter lines (0.4mm wide) for greater strength and stiffness. Print two of the pad parts and one each of the body, jaw, gear and pawl.

After printing, sand down any blobs or lumps on any of the mating surfaces. Using a little Vaseline or light grease on the moving parts will make it operate more smoothly. To assemble, first insert the pawl into the hole in the side of the moving jaw. Then insert the gear into the key-hole shaped slot in the jaw and slide it up towards the pawl. Then slide the moving jaw onto the body. Finally, slide the pads into the dovetail slots on the jaws. Rotate the knob CCW to clamp, press the release lever and rotate the knob CW to unclamp.

CrazyJaw did a great job with his keychain sized heart gears. But if anyone is considering building more than one, it could take a while to print. So, I applied JoeyC's dual-strusion script (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:24195 - which itself is a derivative of thorstadg's work) to print two of each file object(s) at once. To allow this to work, I had to re-organize the objects a little.
  • The large plate is the busiest and had to do some interesting arrangements due to the size of the parts.
  • I doubled up the number of pins so that when dual-struded a complete set is made. Further changes should probably do a full set with one extruder so that dual-struding produces two sets to match the two hearts that are produced.
  • the center.stl file is the original file untouched.
  • the small plate just moves the parts into a vertical line
    • BTW - this was specifically done for a Replicator. The nozzle separation on other printers may require further tweaking.

Download.
Slice normally.
Apply the DualExtrude file to the generated gcode files. (I named my output files with an '_dual.gcode' to help tell the difference)
Run the new GCode through your normal routine. (for me it was open in RepG, and export to .s3g.)

title: DJI Spark Surf Fishing Drop Hook!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
So I was watching this video the other night of a guy surf fishing with a DJI Phantom and he ended up crashing in the ocean. However he had a rather simple yet cool idea for this hook and loop idea to carry his line out into the surf and thought to myself this could be adapted to the DJI Spark as this would the ultimate compact surf fishing rig! Think of how easy this is to take into the field and get up into the air!

So now be forewarned this is all at your own risk and I am still working on this as it is just something I am doing.

Want to know about this design? Well we made a video you can check out here https://youtu.be/tfE-8qvQjJU for info on this project!

In addition it attaches to this landing gear (http://amzn.to/2woMHi4) which you will need. Also these are the white cable ties (http://amzn.to/2wCwjK8) and blacks ones to match (http://amzn.to/2fobEWM). Note the insides of the mounts are tapered to match the legs so make sure to orientate it correctly In addition, if you make one of these please post a make here to help support my designs!

What you don't have a DJI Spark yet! Check them out here (http://amzn.to/2hEenMB), oh wait you do have one? Well check out our curated accessories page here for all things DJI Spark: http://video-drone.diy3dtech.com/dji-spark-accessories/ In addition we also have DJI Spark 3D Print page (http://video-drone.diy3dtech.com/3d-printable-dji-spark-add-ons/) which we also curate here so bookmark it and check back on a regular basis!

Be sure to check out our sister site http://video-drone.diy3dtech.com and related YouTube channel for all things drone!

Also, please follow us on Thingiverse and give this a like if this came in handy and for more information on this project, please visit us at http://www.DIY3DTech.com as well as subscribe to our YouTube Channel at http://YouTube.DIY3DTech.com along with a visit to our drone site and YouTube channel at http://video-drone.DIY3DTech.com

If you are looking for one of a kind swag shop for yourself or a Maker Geek friend, visit our swag shop at http://Swag.DIY3DTech.com for unique 3D Printing, Laser Cutting and CNC swag! Too, if you want a behind the scene look at what we are working on be sure to follow us on Instagram (https://www.instagram.com/diy3dtech/)!

title: Toothbrush Head Stand cnc/laser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Keeping the heads of an electric toothbrush is somehow a pain in the ass. If you put them up they fall over very fast and liquids leave unappetizing residue.

Using a dark acrylic glass (PMMA) I made a holder which can be cleaned with ease and prevents the toothbrush heads from tipping effectively. The recesses are designed to keep the heads in place even if the holder is sloping. You have to remove them by lifting them first.

I cut the material with my Stepcraft desktop cnc-machine and a single-flute 2 mm endmill. Some drops of water with methylated spirits and a little compressed air kept the chips from melting. After cutting I heated up a small strip with a heat gun and carefully bend it to the correct angle. The right part of the drawing can give you a reference, but the exact angle is not that important. Just make sure the top and the bottom parts are parallel.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/ for more interesting designs.

I have not tried to print the stl, it is mainly for viewing, but I suppose that the holder can be printed if you change the orientation accordingly.

extrusionWidth = 5

diameter = 50.8
height = 50.8

I made these a long time ago, but finally decided to publish them.

This is a remix of wylekyot's LED strip. I needed more lighting in my 3D Printer, but wanted something that wasn't bulky, and went with the design of my printer. Plus I wanted it to be strong. The strips are a little thick, and that is because I inset M5 X 10MM (I believe that is the size I used) screw heads just below the LED strip. Then I used M5 T Nut bolts to mount them to the extrusion bars. It gives a clean look to the printer and gives off a TON of light. The strips are 8 inches long, with 2 of them being on every extrusion bar. If you have a different model printer, they could be stretched or shrunk, length wise, for your application. All-in-all, this is one of the simplest, yet practical designs I've made.

I love the originals - these are tweaked to fit the hexes slightly better. I also only remixed the bases with numbers...the stickers are a cool idea, but I like printing! (As per request, I added a plain disc.)

These are modified Gloomhaven bases — I shrunk the base to be 33mm. I re-scaled the numbers to fit the new dial bottom, and slightly moved the conditions shelf in, to fit on the new dial top. I added a hole in the bottom of the dial, to put extra discs beneath. (Each disk is 10 more HP.)

You may need to sand the pegs cleanly after you print...depending on the accuracy of your printer. If your printer is MORE dialed in than mine, perhaps the posts and holes won't match tightly...you can either leave it loose, or modify the remix. :)

EXTRA (2017-11-07):
I came up with a "keyfit" option, to prevent the top coming loose from the dial. There's a photo of it — basically the small spike on the dial, fits through a slot...there's empty space for it to rotate around in the top. (But the spike can only come out when the top is aligned with the "X" on the dial.)

I'll get around to modifying the rest of the dial designs to allow for "keyfit", but I need time to print the other dial designs to make sure they fit nicely. The HP-extend will work on keyfit & normal versions.

author: DDDprinter

description.text: Correctly sized for Nissan 240SX S13 but could work with other models. Print in ABS so it doesn't melt. Four required for a complete set

We built PoKit using a combination of common objects, 3D-printed materials, and laser-cut wood. The items contained in PoKit are listed and described in the file titled objetos_PoKit.pdf

Nuestra PoKit se construyó usando una combinación de objetos comunes, materiales impresos, y madera cortada con láser. Los ítems que contiene el PoKit estan listados y descritos en el archivo objetos_PoKit.pdf y una traducción al español en Guia PoKit - Español.pdf

Box Manufacturing and Assembly

The box's exterior was laser-cut from 6mm thick MDF (medium-density fibreboard). The pieces' "teeth" intertwine to ease the assembly, and they are stuck together with superglue. The lid is attached with hinges. The QR code that is found in the front of the box serve to facilitate access to the documents and forms necessary for a delivery.

To create a box with different dimensions, you may use MakerCase.

The box's internal dividers were laser-cut from 3mm thick MDF and are stuck to the box's interior as shown in the third image.

The second level of dividers (which are placed over the shorter, 3mm high dividers) were 3D-printed.

Fabricación y Montaje de la Caja

El exterior de la caja fue cortado de MDF (6mm grosor) en laser. Los “dientes” de las
piezas entrelazan para facilitar la asamblea y se pegan con pegamento/adhesivo
instantáneo. La tapa se adjunta con bisagras. El código QR que se encuentra en la frente
de la caja sirve para facilitar acceso a los documentos y formularios necesarios para una
entrega.

Para crear una caja de dimensiones diferentes, se puede usar MakerCase.

Los divisores internos de la caja fueron cortados de MDF (3mm de grosor) con láser y se
pegan al interior de la caja como indicado en el dibujo.

El segundo nivel de divisores, que se coloca sobre las divisores más cortos de 3mm de
altura, fue impreso en 3D.

How to assemble the dividers // Cómo poner los divisores. Files/archivos "PoKit_Divisores_Dibujo.pdf" & "Pokit_Laser_Divisores.pdf" File/archivo "laser_pokit_final.pdf" Box's exterior pieces before assembly // Piezas de la caja antes de ensamblar.

For more information // Para más información:
[email protected]

author: getn400mgold

description.text:
Gloomhaven is awesome, but...let's replace the cardboard chits with something more interesting, right?

I found a nice wheeled mech under the Share Alike Creative Commons, and repurposed it.

The Mech a bit bigger. I mounted it to a 33mm Gloomhaven standee base that I had remixed. I cut the object in half, so we could avoid supports at the cost of having to glue them together afterward.

The bottom of the HP dial has a hole, so you can stack "HP extend"ers if your bot has more than 10 health...I haven't gotten far in the game yet, but maybe later? Otherwise, it's not necessary. Better safe than sorry.

EXTRA (2017-11-19):
I came up with a "keyfit" option, to prevent the top coming loose from the dial. Basically a small spike on the bottom dial. The top "key fit" has a slot for the peg to go through and there's empty space for it to rotate around in the top. (But the spike can only come out when the top is aligned with the "X" on the dial.) No support needed.

The HP-extend will work the same on keyfit & normal versions.

description.text:
I just moved back into an apartment complex from a house. The place wasn't furnished and there is a huge granite countertop. The bottom is 31" (non-standard) so I had to either buy adjustable barstools for about $150 a pop or make my own. I found a design online I liked and decided to put together a CAD package to reference during the build process. All design credit goes to Pete (http://www.diypete.com/how-to-make-bar-stools/).

I made a set of these barstools and they turned out very well. I wanted to share my drawing package and models since I found it very beneficial to have. When all was said and done, I think I spent something like $150 making four barstools. Saved me a ton of money and I had a great time doing it.

WARNING: These are pretty heavy. They're each about 35 pounds, give or take 5 pounds.

Credit to the Designer

I actually didn't design the barstools myself. I found these online at DIY with Pete (http://www.diypete.com/how-to-make-bar-stools/).

I wanted a place where I could reference lengths of cuts, part numbers, different measurements, and get all of the design information in one package. I created a model in OnShape and put together some drawings so I could quickly reference instructions.

If you make these, be sure to send some pictures to Pete at http://www.diypete.com.

OnShape Link to Models & Drawings

https://cad.onshape.com/documents/ed256b7d2164a1981d6ff658/v/819e524ca33d0b9d58c71df6/e/427f12f058a9f0d1e393cb51

description.text: This is one of my favorite prints. It is easy, fast and cheep. You have to find a USB with a chip like the one shown in the pictures. The one you need is small (.44 by .6 in). Then all you do is print it out the part and glue or use double sided tape to secure it in. You most likely will need to use a knife to clean out the slit in the part. Lastly in your slicer you need to flip over the piece so it is lying flat everywhere.
